Apr 9

1600 Daily: A Newsletter Nightmare

Let’s put aside our political differences and examine a truly awful newsletter

Each day, I receive an email from the White House.

The email is titled “Your 1600 Daily,” and on some occasions it even has a subtitle (more on that later).

What goodies does it deliver? It’s very often a collection of news, White House happenings, and social media samplings. As a means of spreading information, “1600 Daily” is capable of being highly effective.

The problem is it’s not very well designed. At all.

Given the Trump campaign’s supposed digital fluency — *cough yeah right *cough — it’s a little surprising they don’t appear to give any interest to putting together a solid template, or finding a way to embed photos, or outsourcing work they can’t do, or…simply putting out a newsletter that doesn’t look like it was put together by someone who copy/pasted a Word document with some hyperlinks into a Gmail composition box.

Without any hint of partisan motivation, let’s put aside our differences and consider this newsletter as a technological product. Let’s take a moment to examine, piece by piece, an email newsletter that is really, truly awful.

The Subject Lines

We’re going to start on a positive note. I actually think “1600 Daily” is a fine name for this newsletter. Giving a product an interesting and effective name is not easy, and the Trump camp did a fine job of explaining the frequency of their messaging, creating an expectation, and capturing some brand equity.

I know I’m going to get this in my inbox every day, and I know 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue is where the President lives, so their name selection does a nice job generating a sense that this is news coming straight from the Oval.

The name does this even though it’s obvious it’s not the President himself, but rather Sean Spicer’s team, who manages the newsletter.

But then, we run off the rails pretty quickly. Remember those subtitles we talked about? Here’s a sampling of them:

  • “Repeal and Replace Obamacare, Judge Gorsuch hearing”
  • “President Trump meets with Women in Healthcare panel and Congressional Black Caucus members, Judge Gorsuch confirmation hearing continues”
  • “Weekend Edition”

The first one is fine enough — a brief sampling of the contents of the message. Although they’re not exactly sure how they’re supposed to be using capitalization, that’s understandable. It can be confusing and you don’t get to delete the email and resend it 3 times.

The second is extremely long. Like 2–3 lines on your screen long. They seem to have figured out capitalization, though, so there’s some progress!

The third came last weekend and it was the first “Weekend Edition,” so there may be more of these in the future. Stay tuned!

All of this to say the subject lines aren’t really serving much of a consistent purpose. Why do the subtitles pop up some days, but not others? Are some events just too important? Are they working the lines out with some A/B testing? Or — stay with me here — is it that these are titled by alternating Deputy Communications Directors, one who loves subtitles and one who believes in a short and sweet subject line? Do they give this any thought at all? The world may never know.

The Header Image

This isn’t awful, but why is it so small? Why is there so much space for such a tiny header image? Is the header image overcompensating for something? Is it a metaphor to placate small government conservatives: “Children of Reagan, trust us, we’re working hard on shrinking the size of government.”

Maybe no one in the office knows how to format and design a newsletter? But that can’t be right, because we were promised the very best people would staff up the government.

Seriously, the logo isn’t bad. But it needs to be bigger. And the design should incorporate more features.

The Content

Often, the newsletter will start out with something that’s being featured that day. For example, it might be a weekly address:

or something that supports a goal of the White House:

This isn’t a bad technique — it’s important to address the main points up top! Arc also does that in their “Weekly Arc” newsletter.

The Weekly Arc
April 7, 2017arcdigital.media

Still, there’s not something “featured” every day, which is sort of curious. Sometimes just…like…nothing is worth featuring? Strange for such a busy White House, isn’t it? Again, that’s not a great look that there are only featured items on some days.

(If you’re wondering if those videos are attached or embedded, we’ll get there in a moment.)

If there isn’t anything being featured that day, the newsletter will start with a “White House Memo.” Sometimes this is an actual memo! For example:

Sometimes it is…not an actual memo. Instead it’s what looks suspiciously like a screenshot of a tweet:

After a thorough investigation utilizing a range of decryption techniques, I’ve determined that the above is probably is a screenshot. But it also serves a link to the tweet!

That’s a practice that is repeated over and over again throughout the newsletter. The “1600 Daily” embeds are usually always screenshots of various social media posts, videos, whatever, that also act as links to those posts without saying anything about the practice or warning users that they’ll be sent to the site if they click on the image. Sometimes they just sort of throw a “retweet” under a post that readers can see is from Twitter:

The “Retweet” here is not really a Call To Action so much as a sort of half-hearted suggestion. For the record, the newsletter never really offers readers the chance — no, the opportunity — to follow the White House on any social channels, nor does it call out any of its social channels at all. The screenshots and links are just kind of there.

After the memos/random tweets, we then move on to the President’s Daily Schedule, which is the kind of interesting, regularly accessible piece of content that probably belongs in the newsletter.

Not so bad, although some additional context might be helpful. Also, telling someone in an email to “Watch LIVE” when they might not open the message until after the event is a questionable technique.

Labeling-wise, the Daily Schedule typically involves a mix of simultaneously vague and overly specific information about what the President is doing. For example: “President Trump signs S.442"; “President Trump signs an Executive Order Establishing Enhanced Collection and Enforcement of Antidumping and Countervailing Duties and Violations of Trade and Customs Laws.” Can we find a happy medium?

The rest of the email is split into a few sections that contain varying amounts of content. The titles and sections change from day to day: “From President Trump”; “Get Involved”; “Oval Office Highlights”; “White House Updates”; “Press Room”; and “News Reports,” among others.

As you may be able to tell from the titles, these get pretty repetitive. With the exception of “Get Involved” — which mixes Calls To Action such as “vote in our photo contest,” “sign this petition for Gorsuch,” and “share your Obamacare disaster story” — the same content usually appears several times.

For example, “Oval Office Highlights” might include a link to a video of Trump hosting some sort of panel. Then “White House Updates” might include a photo of the same panel. “Press Room” usually showcases the briefing from the day before, where Press Secretary Spicer discusses that same panel as an upcoming event, while “News Reports” is a curated list of articles that present what the White House is doing in a positive light.

That is, except the time they were tricked by a satirical article they obviously didn’t read entitled “Trump’s Budget Makes Perfect Sense and Will Fix America, and I Will Tell You Why.” Whoops.

Opinion | Trump's budget makes perfect sense and will fix America, and I will tell you why
Some people are complaining that the budget proffered by the Trump administration, despite its wonderful macho-sounding…www.washingtonpost.com

All of this to say, there’s often quite a bit going on in the email, and it’s usually lots of the same content repackaged in a variety of transparently uncoordinated ways.

It doesn’t appear that there is much messaging or strategy here beyond “throw everything we’ve got into this email!”, and there is very little they’re offering that you couldn’t get somewhere else. “Get Involved” does provide some purpose for the newsletter, but not much, and almost never at the top level.

Quags’ Favorite Features

After reading this newsletter for a few weeks, some highlights stood out.

First, the Photo of the Day and its accompanying text:

Take a look at the photo. Now take a look at the link under the photo that tells you to “View Photo.” Curious as to whether it’s a different photo? It’s not. It’s the same photo. You’re already viewing it. Gotcha loser!

Is this the one and only time they’ve done this? Let me answer that with a question of my own: Have you read any of this piece thus far?

There is one feature I genuinely like. It’s something I’d present differently, but it works as an example of the kind of interesting content a White House newsletter might want to consider including more regularly.

I give you the Oval Office in 360 degrees.

Well, I don’t give you that, I just give you the evidence that they’ve given you that — provided you click through to Facebook. Still, they’ve done the 360-degree thing a few times now, and it’s cool. Despite the predictably cliché golden curtains, the White House is an obviously interesting place and the current administration is in a unique position to exclusively showcase it.

There’s one last feature I want to highlight. It’s something I find inexplicable and hilarious. It’s something I find darkly unsettling. It’s something I find myself rapidly scrolling through every day and yet, something I can never fully make sense of.

It’s a giant blank space, a white space, at the bottom of every single “Daily 1600.”

Why is there a giant white space after the “News Reports” section? Again here:

Just a browser issue, right? Or perhaps it’s a desktop issue. Nope. Here it is on mobile:

Why is this blank space the most consistent feature of “Daily 1600”? Is someone hitting return 12 times before sending these emails? Are they doing it intentionally, so you really know that you’ve finished reading Your Daily 1600? Is it some kind of metaphor for the emptiness the staffer feels throwing these things together at 7:00 AM each morning? Is it a cry for help?

If you’re out there, “Daily 1600” editor, we’re here for you. Get in touch!

Or, you know, hire a designer.
